title: 110_s1582
content:
The Act titled "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008" includes definitions for various terms. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892) amends Section 303 by defining "hydrographic data" as information acquired through various surveying methods and used in providing hydrographic services. "Hydrographic services" include the management, maintenance, interpretation, certification, and dissemination of bathymetric and hydrographic data. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 defines "hydrographic services" as the management, maintenance, interpretation, certification, and dissemination of various types of information, including nautical charts and databases, derived from hydrographic data. It also includes the development of nautical information systems and related activities. The functions of the Administrator are outlined in Section 3. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892a) is amended to promote safe, efficient, and environmentally sound marine transportation by providing hydrographic services and fulfilling the purposes of the Act. The Administrator is authorized to procure, lease, evaluate, test, develop, and operate. The Administrator may procure, lease, evaluate, test, develop, and operate vessels, equipment, and technologies for safe navigation and hydrographic data acquisition. They shall design, install, maintain, and operate real-time hydrographic monitoring systems to enhance navigation safety. Additionally, they may acquire hydrographic data to support coastal and ocean resource conservation. The Administrator may acquire hydrographic data and provide services to support conservation, manage resources, save lives, protect property, and resume commerce during emergencies. They may also create joint centers with other agencies to fulfill the Act's purposes. The Administrator, under the Reform Act of 2006, has the authority to create joint centers with other entities to carry out the Act's purposes and award contracts for hydrographic data acquisition. SEC. 4. HYDROGRAPHIC SERVICES REVIEW PANEL. The panel will consist of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator, with nonvoting members from the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and NOAA. Members must be qualified in disciplines related to hydrographic data and services, marine transportation, port administration, and other relevant fields. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 306 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to authorize appropriations. Authorized appropriations for nautical mapping and charting functions under sections 304 and 305, including hydrographic surveys, are as follows:
- $55,000,000 for fiscal year 2009
- $56,000,000 for fiscal year 2010
- $57,000,000 for fiscal year 2011
- $58,000,000 for fiscal year 2012
Additionally, funding for contracting hydrographic surveys and operating survey vessels is allocated as follows:
- $32,130,000 for fiscal year 2009
- $32,760,000 for fiscal year 2010
- $33,390,000 for fiscal year 2011
- $34,020,000 for fiscal year 2012
Total funding for these activities is specified for each fiscal year. Authorized appropriations for nautical mapping and charting functions under sections 304 and 305, including hydrographic surveys, are as follows:
- $25,900,000 for fiscal year 2009
- $26,400,000 for fiscal year 2010
- $26,900,000 for fiscal year 2011
- $27,400,000 for fiscal year 2012
Funding for operating hydrographic survey vessels owned by the United States is allocated as follows:
- $32,640,000 for fiscal year 2009
- $33,280,000 for fiscal year 2010
- $33,920,000 for fiscal year 2011
- $34,560,000 for fiscal year 2012
Tide and current measurement functions funding under this title is specified for each fiscal year. Authorized appropriations for tide and current measurement functions under this title are as follows:
- $27,000,000 for fiscal year 2009
- $27,500,000 for fiscal year 2010
- $28,000,000 for fiscal year 2011
- $28,500,000 for fiscal year 2012
Additionally, $75,000,000 is allocated for acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel capable of staying at sea continuously for at least 30 days. SEC. 6 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Commissioned Officer Corps Act of 2002 is amended to increase the total number of authorized commissioned officers from 321 to 379, subject to certain conditions being met.
